[[div class="email"]]
[[div class="tofrom"]]
@@ @@
[[size 131%]]**This tale contains:**[[/size]]
@@ @@
[[/div]]

* Mild non-explicit consensual intimate/sexual content, mostly ##purple|innuendo##
* Interactive (collapsible) content: blue text is clickable
* Not a lot of action (sorry, action lovers)
* Not even a lot of //things happening// (sorry, things-happening lovers)
* Slice-of-life: an uneventful but consequential weekend
* Modernist pastiche (oh, //that's// why there's not a lot happening)
* Bad poetry //**(you've been warned)**//
* Good poetry (stolen from public domain content)
* Mangling of good poetry (modified from public domain content)
* Secret stuff for the puzzle-lovers (about that: see below)

[[div class="tofrom"]]
@@ @@
[[size 131%]]**EDITORS! This tale also contains "puzzle elements":**[[/size]]
@@ @@
[[/div]]

* Weird notation for sighs, namely (.) and (..).
* Unusual //(and intentionally inconsistent)// [transcription] [NOTATION].
* Intentional "errors" — most notably, it's conspicuously missing a few words here and there (representing removed data) without [EXPUNGED] or other usual cues except occasionally a —
* Text in color, a ##500|dark red## and a ##purple|purple##, which were intentionally chosen to be somewhat similar and also chosen to look somewhat similar to [https:// hyperlinks] (an accessibility-friendly option will be generated in March if the tale sticks around that long)
* --Abundant-- //Excessive// use of the em dash — in the normal ways and also in all the places where the en dash would be "correct" and also to represent certain expungements, e.g. email username@ — (worst of all, many dashes are ambiguous, they might represent expungement or be punctuation)
* "An obscene number of ellipses."
* Adverbs.

Please __do__ mention potential errors in the comments.

[[/div]]

@@ @@
[[div class="email"]]
[[div class="tofrom"]]


[[include :scp-wiki:component:coltop show=A note about puzzles|hide=A note about puzzles]]

Yes, there is a //stupid// amount of 'bonus content' in here.[!-- including content for three separate as-yet-undocumented anomalies, an entire charted-out fake history of no fewer than three intermediate editor characters each with their own agendas, and references to dozens of SCP articles that are interpretive and contextualizing rather than referential, i.e. the surrounding passage serves as commentary on the linked article rather than just saying "hey reader this is referring to this other article"... with eventual plans for CSS to load different hyperlinks each time... --]

Please, though, **just don't worry about that stuff //unless you enjoy it//**. I did my best to make the 'bonus content' minimally obtrusive. Just, like, read and have fun, and if there's a word apparently missing, blow it off and let your brain fill in what seems like it should go there, you'll be fine. So what if you don't guess the exact same word or phrase or name that I had in mind? You'll be fine. We'll be fine. I promise.

[!-- To the best of my ability, there is no encoded or encrypted content anywhere in this text file or in this tale. For the love of all that is lovable, please don't sit down with a notepad and try to string the fifth word of each paragraph together or something. I promise that nothing is arbitrarily obscured, and you already know how to un-obscure the content and see it — I can say that here because you're obviously already reading page source or doing some other trick to obtain access to comment content, so you know how to find everything. "Put in the comments" (in-universe as well as in-real-life) is as hidey as it gets. The rest is all "but what does this mean?" stuff. If you enjoy that, well, this tale won't keep the professors //busy for centuries//, but it has //things to say//. You know what I mean.

I'm even going to spoiler the only other thing: wikipedia has the original Ace of Wands, with links to Waite's commentary on its meaning. The version of the Ace of Wands that appears in this tale has some very specific and very intended changes and omissions (as a footnote clarifies, in-universe they specifically have access to Waite's commentary and would regard it as authoritative, so some of the changes may be deliberate on the part of the character who drew the image; furthermore, Waite's book is in the public domain, so we know the present-day redactor/reader characters have access to it. Some omissions may simply reflect laziness on the part of the copier, and their meaningfulness is unintended in-universe).
--]

[!--
Act titles taken from public domain works:
* "The reticent volcano keeps / His never slumbering plan" — Emily Dickinson, "The reticent volcano keeps" pub. posthumously 1924
* "I shall know you, secrets / by the litter you have left / and by your bloody footprints." — Lola Ridge, "Secrets" 1920
* "Il n’y pas de modèle pour qui cherche ce qu’il n’a jamais vu. A la fin, rien n’est aussi beau qu’une ressembance involontaire." — Pablo Picasso, attributed 1910, quoted by Paul Éluard, "To Give What They See" 1939 (If I may loosely translate: "There's no role-model for those who seek a thing they've never seen. In the end, there's nothing as beautiful as an involuntary resemblance." The original quote is not about what it means to be synonymous, but rather about freedom of expression and the experience of collaboration. But if a sentence can't serve at least two purposes, then it probably wasn't a sentence spoken by Picasso.)
* "From the same source I have not taken / My sorrow — I could not awaken / My heart to joy at the same tone — / And all I lov’d — I lov’d alone — / Then — in my childhood — in the dawn / Of a most stormy life — was drawn / From ev’ry depth of good and ill / The mystery which binds me still — " — Edgar Allen Poe, "Alone" (I know, I know. At least it wasn't a quote from The Raven.)
* "Sir, more than kisses, letters mingle souls, / For thus, friends absent speak. This ease controls / The tediousness of my life" — John Donne, "To Sir Henry Watton" pub. posthumously 1635 (The original quote is not about literature or glyphs; he's literally writing a letter to his friend.)
* "that which was lacking on all your well-fill’d shelves, yet needed most, I bring" — Walt Whitman, "Shut Not Your Doors" 1855
--]

--]








[!-- This space intentionally left blank. --]








[!--

[!--
NOTICE FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF INTRANET FILTRATION
(FORMERLY RAISA DIVISION OF FLAGGING FOR EXPUNGEMENT OR REDACTION)

This is an automated message authorized by DIF to be inserted into every text file flagged for review during our jurisdiction-expansion.

Ordinarily the jurisdiction of DIF is review of submitted documentation to identify, characterize, document, and then expunge breaches of information security and violations of Foundation privacy protocols, e.g. inappropriate assignment of too low a clearance level for access to specific names or dates. If you haven't heard of us, then congratulations are in order, as it means you and the employees under your purview have not been found to have violated the specific infosec/privacy protocols our automated systems assess and flag, and/or that you have passed any manual audits resulting from said flags. Due to the technological tools and infrastructure at our disposal, our department has been conscripted to assist with the investigation of Potentially Anomalous Phenomenon 2309-2514 (informally, -2514). Accordingly, receiving a notification that DIF has flagged files under your purview may not be a cause for concern; look for "2514" in the REFERENCE field.

One or more sections of this text file have been reviewed by DIF in response to automated and/or manual flags. Unflagged portions have been ignored unless the redactor saw fit to extend the scope of a flag. To ensure the integrity of DIF redactor notes, they have been recorded in audio format (see attached) and locked with standard level security (3/Secret). That file should be considered the authoritative DIF record when experienced acoustically (transcripts and TTS are unreliable). To facilitate efficient review, and make it easier for a reviewer to match audio commentary with the text the comment is about, a (partial) written record has been added to this file (as tags); however, any written record should be considered incomplete and unreliable. All redactions and expungements, both proposed and enacted, have been comprehensively documented in the audio file.

Formally, it is not our purview to assess qualities of the documentation unrelated to -2514 (or information security and privacy, as per usual). Informally, I have asked our reviewers to adopt a "if you see something, say something" approach. My reasoning is simple: -2514 is a subject of current research, and when investigating a PAP, more information is better than less. In many cases, reviewers will simply "flag & tag" proper nouns, because -2514-associated phenomena is thought to affect them in particular.

If you disagree with a redactor's assessment in a matter of consequence, you may request a review from a supervisor redactor. (Some files may trigger flags at different times. Previously reviewed files are automatically assigned to a supervisory redactor, in case the previous redactor in fact triggered the flagging.) We ask that you do not request review of inconsequential flags that did not result in expungement, revision, or punitive consequences.

Tags generated by other services prior to our review will be automatically reformatted to ALL CAPS in this file for ease of distinction. Consult a previous iteration of the document if this reformatting results in ambiguity or cause for concern.

—Sierra Cunix
Assistant Director, DIF
--]

[[# I]]
[[div class="scenenumber"]]
I
[[/div]]

[[div class="modernday"]]

[[div class="dateheader"]]
[[[secure-facility-dossier-site-55|Site 55 • H Wing]]]
Laboratory RA302 (formerly Laboratory HC328)[!-- Recalcitrant Anomalies getting their own dedicated labs instead of sharing labs with miscellaneous other departments was a new-ish development in 2011 --]
September 22, 2011 • Friday
[[/div]]

Before the smoke can clear, before the gong can fade to silence, a fox-fur-gloved hand reaches forward, firmly grasps the leftmost of the wardrobe's twin doors, and tugs — twice — to no avail.

"Mm. Well," says Andrews, marking on a clipboard, "It was worth a try."

There was a time when Cecilia would have nodded in agreement. There was a time when she would have at least put on a thin and tolerant smile. There was a time, even, when she would have offered Andrews an annoyed sideways glare, followed by a sigh tacitly acknowledging that her frustration was not with him. But those times have all come and gone: this latest failure was the seventy-fourth experiment they've run on SCP-9291-A this week, at least the two hundredth this month, and roughly the thousandth buoyant "it was worth a try" that Cecilia has had to endure on this assignment; the finer points of her personality have been ground coarse and then smooth, eroded by relentless tedium; her face does nothing, her grip loosens, her arm falls back, her eyes track her arm as it falls back … hmm … not lifelessly, //per se//, but not with natural ease … more of a hydraulics-tempered motion … robotically, she decides, without much satisfaction. How did people describe robotic behavior back before robots were a thing? Mechanically, maybe? Nah, still too neoteric, too narrowly technical. She could always check with Oscar...

Hardly relevant, in any case, to this godforsaken impenetrable edifice of stately antique furniture, steadfastly refusing to manifest its anomalous properties, like a grinning older brother withholding his latest yo-yo trick because he's enjoying the poke-and-prod attention from those who actually want to see it.[[footnote]]But only once. Nobody cares about seeing your double on trapeze for the second time. They go back to being adults.[[/footnote]] Of course, that's generally how researching these "recalcitrant" anomalous objects goes: nearly ninety-nine percent of the time spent standing idle while wishing that something, anything, would happen, followed by one percent spent diving for cover while wishing it hadn't.[[footnote]]The most apt kids' game analogy is probably Red Light, Green Light (led by a Red Light enthusiast), but what comes to mind for Cecilia is a variant of Duck, Duck, Goose.[[/footnote]] (And maybe, in the in-between, that tantalizing slimmest rounding-error of probability, triumph //without// tragedy — )

[[div class="disconnection"]]
 — Suddenly acutely and paralytically aware that time has been passing in what people less prone to wandering thoughts tend to call "uncomfortable silence" — with only the hiss of the outgassing fog machine for comfort — and that's not much comfort — Cecilia begins to hum a soft monotone to herself, a habit she has tried diligently to avoid indulging while at work —
[[/div]]

Andrews, either a born natural at consummate professionalism or still young enough to have the energy to feign it, is exactly as oblivious to her unresponsiveness as polite decency requires. He checks his wristwatch.[[footnote]]A recently-inherited treasure, currently worn on the distal side and lacquered on the back with acrylic nail polish, because it was giving him a rash. The nail polish was Cecilia's idea; Andrews had tried covering it in contact paper.[[/footnote]] "It's quarter to. We might have time for one more reset if we use the same fogger base?"

By the time he finishes asking the question, Cecilia has lifted the mask off her head and started to peel off one of the gloves, sticky with perspiration. "Eh, let's not. Stopping now gives us time to clean up and file for the week and cruise out of here right at five."

"Look at you, boss lady, aiming for a timely clock-ouout." The last word is a muffed, distended mess, interrupted by the pops of Andrews's back cracking as he shelves the clipboard, folders the checklist, kills the Bunsen[!-- Robert Bunsen --] burner (which really should have been done //before// the test), pulls the fuel tubing, and leans on the peninsula, wincing for a little longer than ordinary fatigue would explain away. Cecilia feels her brows furrow. He's too young for degenerative lumbar problems, isn't he?[[footnote]]Twenties, thirties? Hmm … he's been Foundation eight years, has a pre-med bachelor's, a likely fiver, nobody gets out in four anymore, plus I bet his younger self was a backpacking gap-year kind of guy, so … 18+6+8, thirty-two? Give or take. She could double-check his doss on SCiPNet, but jeez. When did she lose the ability to discern someone's age? Do they all just look like kids now? Oh god, they do, don't they. Like kids. Like someone else's kids.[[/footnote]]

He rallies impressively, exhales with a forced smile. "I mean hey, that works for me, Mom's flying in for the wake and I could use more time to tidy up and maybe see to fixing the strut on the trundle." As Cecilia makes a mental note to look up what a trundle is and whether it's something specific to Scottish-American funeral practices (and also: //are// there Scottish-American funeral practices?), Andrews waggles his eyebrows. "How 'bout you, boss? Big weekend plans?"

Cecilia could suppress the wild goofy can't-keep-a-secret grin that springs to her face, but chooses not to — she almost, almost, almost replies "probably diving down a Wikipedia rabbit hole about trundles;" it's achingly tempting; but she thinks better of it — "Oh, you know me. Always."

He doesn't actually know her //that// well, of course — she's not much of a "chat about life outside work during work" person — but hey, let the man wonder. Surely it can't hurt to spark a little mystery now and then.

[[/div]] [!-- END MODERNDAY INDICATOR --]

[[# II]]
[[div class="scenenumber"]]
II
[[/div]]

[[div class="oldtimey"]]

[[div class="dateheader"]]
Boston, MA • 55 Beacon St.
Headquarters House[!-- a townhouse residence; J.A. Prufrock was a close relation of Augusta Peabody, apparently had an informal ongoing tenancy arrangement that included use of the study; at that time, and to this day, the location (now a museum) was/is primarily known for W.H. Prescott's earlier tenancy there, with Prufrock relegated to an aside --]
September 22, 1911 • Friday
[[/div]]

The man, standing scrunched up and coiled over the drink he's been nursing and the flame that illuminates this little corner of the study, suppresses another sneeze. The crisp rectangle he holds addresses its intended recipient by the initials J.A.R.; it is no Post Card, no chic trend for requesting one's presence at a supper over an artificial-silk tablecloth, but rather a sealed letter of conventional proportions and genteel purport; it bears a mark in one corner, not a post-mark Washington in his reds or greens, but a dutifully traced Symbol of the Minor Arcana,[[footnote]]While Mr. De Laurence would no doubt be furious at such a brazen appropriation from his Illustrated Key, it is simply a consequence of his great success; there are many nowadays whose erudition extends so far as the Tarot, and no small number, even, who would adopt an Arcanum for the signature of their burgeoning Hermetic Order or Society. That Mr. L.W. De Laurence himself pirated "his" work in its entirety from A.E. Waite and P.C. Smith would not factor into his anger or its expression; the guilty are the fastest to decry another's trespass.[[/footnote]] //viz.//:[!-- metadata evidence suggests the above description predates the scanned-in image as well as the digital reconstruction of the envelope, it's unknown why text descriptions were retained after the images became available --]

[[div class="papernote"]]
[[>image https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/local--files/collocations/ace-of-wands.png width="15%" alt="The Tarot card Ace of Wands" text="Ace of Wands" link="ace-of-wands.png"]]
[[div class="initials"]]
J.A.R.
[[div class="spacer"]]
@@ @@[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT --]
[[/div]] [!-- BLANK --]
[[/div]] [!-- END HANDWRITING APPROXIMATION --]
[[/div]] [!-- END TEXTURED REPRESENTATION --]

Exquisitely discreet, exquisitely cryptic.

However palpable the sense of intended mystery may be, the man has no doubts regarding the provenance of the invitation, and is cognizant of the likely urgency of a timely reply. Nevertheless, he merely holds and gazes at the envelope, turning it ever-so-slowly, in a manner that might seem reverent if he looked even a little less unhappy.

The desk is as barren as the room is sparsely furnished — some papers, a screw-cap [!-- even though "" describes the style of filler, the term is a trademark in good standing --] pen, the candle-holder and the glass (and a bottle of — [!-- the first commercially available bourbon; notably the  —s' facility experienced a fire in 1910, making a supply of their whiskey a somewhat rarer and more prized commodity --] that would normally be tucked away). There is no letter-opener at the ready, or even in the desk-drawers; this is no accident; they are much too messy, either sharp enough to draw beads of blood or, more commonly, dull enough to merely tear; one might as well be brandishing a crustacean claw. No, the attentive and respectful way to open an envelope of this import is by the warmth of a candle, by warmth and patience[[footnote]]Such a method, when reversible, could be used for nefarious meddling or covert espionage; accordingly, an attentive sender of sensitive materials would have introduced confounding factors, perhaps by impressing the wax with a unique and delicate embossment, or by lacing ribbon underneath the seal, or even by use of highly textured envelope-paper; it is reasonable to conclude that the originator of this particular communication is not well-versed in long-established methods of containing, securing, and protecting information, and the sealed structure of the package is merely an amateur's affectation.[[/footnote]] … Coax the wax into its primordial state, until paper parts from paper … Like — so —

With a nearly-inaudible pop, the contents are his to retrieve and unfold; he stretches, sits, settles in, and proceeds:

[[div class="papernote"]]
[[div class="letter"]]
@@ @@
Our dear Brother awaiting Dawn,
@@ @@
It is with all available pleasure that I announce to you the Preliminary Finding of this Lodge:
 — that your Ingenium is in consonance with the Great Work of our Society;
 — that its Perturbation is luminous in its current and patent meaning, and so a worthy offering to the Divine Light of ##500|Kaether##;
 — that we find your Art, in short, **Considerable.**
[[/div]]
[[/div]]

Purple prose and extravagant Capitalization aside, this is, undoubtedly, the best news this sort of missive could possibly bear, but no joy finds the man's face, and no excitement quickens his heart. He merely reads on, with attenuated glumness perhaps better suited to news of some tragedy overseas, or the death of a distant relative, or a dinner-roll dropped buttered-side-down onto a rug.

[[div class="papernote"]]
[[div class="letter"]]
The consideration we extend to you is Induction by initiatory Ritual of the Transfiguration Grade 0@< >@=@< >@0; the first Purification, that your form and vibration may become unutterably splendid to ##500|Kaether##; that your Art and Essence may be put before ##500|Kaether## and beheld by us all, and thereby dissolved to Coincide; that you may be opened up to your fullest luminous Presence before what can only be described as a crowning achievement of the highest Age.
[[/div]]
[[/div]]

The greater portion of this passage merely conforms to the eclectic flourishes customary to Hermetic Orders, or Societies, or whatever faddish appellation the socialites and public intellectuals are bestowing upon themselves and their closest associates at the moment, but the last line hoists the man's attention from its stupor (and he stands as he reads it) — why, wasn't the //Traveller//[!--the Boston "Daily Evening Traveller" --] just blaring about some stolen priceless sculpture, said to be a never-previously-exhibited work of Michelangelo himself, copped en route to its exhibition? — and the would-be exhibitor himself (here the man retrieves a newspaper, consults it) was quoted proclaiming the work to be —

[[div class="papernote" style="font-family: Old Standard TT, serif; width: 50%; max-width: 20em;"]]
"a crowning achievement of the Renaissance giant."
[[/div]]

[[size 131%]] — ! — [[/size]] [!-- the isolated punctuation marks ! (and ?, below) might be evidence of incomplete expunging or interference but probably not, is more likely to be evoking a likely-apochryphal alleged exchange between Victor Hugo and his publisher (allegation origin thought to be Handy-Book of Literary Curiosities by William S. Walsh, pub. 1892, public domain) --]

…

(Maybe just … Or could they truly have … And why else would … Then perhaps … ?)

And after all, the man considers, is Charles's culpability, perhaps only as accessory after the fact, truly inconceivable? He has been reacquainting himself with the enterprises of some old prisoner-of-war comates, potential "business acquaintances" … men of ambitious and irregular character…

Hm.

[[div class="papernote"]]
[[div class="letter"]]
There will be a Lodge-hall ceremony thereafter to welcome all our new Brothers and honor the Equinox, and also a supper. Please find enclosed Instructions with regard to time and place and Necessity, with a combination of Numbers to be kept on your person and in strictest confidence, for to pass the Lodge gate, they must be indicated in the enumerated order exactly.
@@ @@
Join our tapers in the Darkness, come and see what appears from Within.
@@ @@
Yours in LVX and its Shadow,
[[image https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/local--files/collocations/Charles-Follen-Adams-signature.png link="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Follen_Adams" style="max-height:3em;" alt="signed, Charles Follen Adams" text="Charles Follen Adams"]]
@@ @@
[[/div]]
[[/div]]

Hmph... Appalling, truthfully, that men of the caliber of Yeats[!-- W.B. Yeats, renowned poet --] and his theater-friends find these eccentricities so appealing. The sooner that everyone tires of and abandons all this occultist affectation, the better. But one does what one must with the circumstances as they are…

With reinstituted glumness, the man moves automatically, instinctively, to crumple the whole thing up and be done with it, to roll their world into a ball and feel it become rubbish — he almost, almost, almost indulges the urge, but stops himself — glances over the second paragraph again, lingering… and, at last, makes a Decision.[!-- capitalization reflects both determination to delve deeper into this Order and their Quirks, and a recognition that this is a decision of unusual importance --]

With renewed vitality, he unscrews the pen-cap, scrabbles for a clean sheet of note-paper, and sets to briskly copying down times and places and Necessities; then, after a precise refolding and replacement, and while straining to peer out the window to gauge how much time is left in the day, he begins to warm the wax again.

[[/div]] [!-- END OLDTIMEY INDICATOR --]

[[# III]]
[[div class="scenenumber"]]
III
[[/div]]

[[div class="modernday"]]

[[div class="dateheader athome"]]
##black|██████##, ##black|██## •##black|██## ##black|█████## St.[!-- Dossier says 2 Cross St., Andover, MA. Original redactor seems to have chosen a curious strategy to obscure the single-digit number by smearing the analog redaction; this also might have been unintentional. --]
Dominguez/Hartford residence
September 22, 2011 • Friday evening
[[/div]]

It surprises no one that Cecilia keeps a paper diary that no one gets to see.[[footnote]]With notably rare exceptions, such as whenever they peek over her shoulder in the Site cafeteria, conspicuously inconspicuous, reading or pretending to read while waiting for her to notice and shoo them away.[[/footnote]] It might surprise some that lately it's practically a dictionary, almost superseding its (generally much more entertaining) role as a repository of quips and banter.[[footnote]]The diary itself has //many// purposes, at least one of which is phatic, which requires that it be seen. The idea to use "Stardate" was inspired by the same colleague who for unfathomable reasons developed the habit of calling her "Captain," whom she aggravates in turn with "May a Force be with you" salutations. Mutual annoyance is the better part of workplace camaraderie.[[/footnote]]^^,@@ @@^^[[footnote]]Tom practically howled in triumph when he espied the Stardate label: "A-ha! I knew you were a nerd!" At that she smiled sweetly, with mission accomplished, and raised a shushing finger to her lips. Then winked. Camaraderie is the better part of workplace morale.[[/footnote]] The reason for this shift is principally technological: Cecilia discovered that she has access to the transcripts her cellphone's autorecord "feature" generates, and can export clips, even; no more struggling to remember just how someone phrased something.

The shorthand can be a little inscrutable, but Cecilia (generally) doesn't care if her spying colleagues learn her Word of the Day (for those times when she does care about successful over-the-shoulder communication, suddenly everything is painstakingly written in full).

[[div class="diary"]]
[[collapsible show="Stardate 110923." hide="Stardate 110923."]]
WotD __Collocation__, n.[!-- noun --] W[!-- Webster's --] def.[!-- definition --] pretty funny considering how we use it — it's a natural-sounding word pair, not idiom but swapping out either word for a synonym would make it sound unnatural. With natural/un[!-- unnatural --] defined by like, vibes.[!-- Possibly intended as an abbreviation of vibration or vibrator; no documentation, current or contemporaneous with 2011, of the word "vibes" have been located; online searches propose it is an error, and the only examples obtained from social media content database queries were obvious user typos or misspellings. ETBETR.[!-- "Early to bed, early to rise." From a verse of advice in Poor Richard's Almanac, pub. by Ben Franklin in 1735. Public domain. This initialism has made appearances in a wide variety of contemporary merchandise, but no copyright claim has been established (or if it has, the results must have either been subsequently expunged or retrocausally removed). Sudden proliferation and equally sudden disappearance of the initialism in zeitgeist could reflect anomalous influences, or could have resulted from non-anomalous vendor copycat practices and typical usage trajectories for slang (ETBETR quickly acquired a "Live, Laugh, Love" style reputation as mockworthy, cringe, lame, etc. but does not appear to have acquired a comparable enduring fanbase). While merchandise with this initialism is no longer widely available for purchase, procured items have not disappeared or had their text altered. There is little to no use of ETBETR as a parting acknowledgement observed in current verbal exchanges for which we have recording data. Current online search engines return offers to unscramble BETTER rather than initialism definitions, with little to no evidence of its 2011 use; this could be non-anomalous, as search engines from 2012 to present have engaged in a modernization process commonly known as enshittification, which (in addition to other initiatives) deprecates older content and displaces it from search results. Available audio logs from the time period do reflect the commonplace spoken use of the phrase, indicating that whatever phenomena may be at work here (if any) does not alter audio files. Likewise, physically generated manifestations (such as those in Cecilia's diaries, or the aforementioned merchandise) appear to have persisted. It is possible, though increasingly unlikely, that the phenomenon was singularly analog for some unknown reason and that its apparent lack of use in digital text communication (SMS, social media, etc.) is non-anomalous. Research into whether online content from 2011 have been scrubbed is ongoing. --]

Her midnight sneak[[footnote]]Cecilia's newfound fondness for collocations (like "[[[scp-100-it|midnight snack]]]") does not eclipse her love of puns and plays-on-words.[[/footnote]] goes undiaried: pickles straight from the jar, one-handed, because the other's busy holding open the slim paperback //Robinson, Prufrock, Adams: Modernism's Lost Pilgrims//[!-- written by Shin Jae-Beom (no relation to the actor) and published in 1994, copyright reacquired by the author in 1999 specifically to release it into public domain in its entirety, a practice remarkable at the time but increasingly common among academics. --] and page-turning with practiced dexterity.[[footnote]]The trick to this is to place the middle finger on the spine for leverage, put the index finger in the crease between pages to hold the book open, and turn the page by feathering it apart from the rest with the thumb and then maneuvering the index finger clockwise or counterclockwise as necessary to finish the transition and secure the new crease. How to manage this for heavier volumes is left as an exercise for the reader.[[/footnote]]

Having gotten about a quarter into it (with plenty of jumping around), Cecilia has settled on some preliminary verdicts:

* Robinson seems like kind of a hack, the type who nowadays would have excessively strong opinions about feminists and regional microbreweries[[footnote]]Mr. Jeremiah A. Robinson did not drink alcohol, as he believed it interfered with his "natural energies;" his beverages of choice were teas that vendors assured him had been sourced exclusively from Ceylon, apparently a sufficiently exotic location to have a most excellent mystical energy. As his opinions on the "scourge of the New Woman" speak for themselves, they need not be addressed here.[[/footnote]] (this is neither a preliminary verdict nor a new opinion, as she was already quite familiar with him from SCP-9291-A-related research into his Hermetic Order of choice);
* Prufrock's early stuff[[footnote]]Inexplicably glossed as "juvenilia" even though the poems were published in his twenties and thirties?! Cecilia is apparently not the only one who sees 'em all as kids these days.[[/footnote]] comes across as a vivid surrealist type with an intensely melancholy whiskey-breathed maturity, but ohmygod is he ever a guy's guy;
* Adams is humorous and pleasantly conventional, but tying him in with the others as a "Lost Pilgrim" feels like a tendentious stretch only attempted because everything's gotta be grouped in threes. Heaven forbid someone deign to write about just //two// people.

[[div class="spacer"]]
[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK --]
[[/div]]

[[div class="poem-text"]]
Let us go then, you and I,
When the evening is spread out against the sky
Like a patient etherised upon a table;
Let us go, through certain half-deserted streets,
The muttering retreats
Of restless nights in one-night cheap hotels
And sawdust restaurants with oyster-shells:
Streets that follow like a tedious argument
Of insidious intent
To lead you to an overwhelming question...
Oh, do not ask, "What is it?"
Let us go and make our visit.

…just a few lines into the first stanza, already oblivious to mere mortal matters of time and space and necessity, she puts the pickle-jar back without looking at it, unaware that it's unlidded; in fact, her eyes don't leave the book-pages until she's sprawled on the landing and oh! — mph! — indeed, here she is at the top of the stairs and sprawled on the landing, clenching her jaw and squeezing her eyes shut, processing, processing. Mph. There is a fifteen-second wordless pandemonium of undifferentiated pain-impulses; eventually, her left foot helpfully reports in that she has stubbed her toe and please let's not be doing that; //eventually// eventually, as her forearms throb to the tempo of her heartbeat, her left wrist begins to have Opinions. By this time she is back to thinking thoughts: "Well, //that'll// bruise," and, "Now I really do need to think of something exciting to pretend to have done this weekend," and, "You're too old to be going up the stairs inattentively. Be better."

[[div class="spacer"]]
[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK --]
[[/div]]

Sitting on the top step, she eyes the book (which skidded down the hall and sits splayed chaotically, lit by the hallway night-light and casting grandiose shadows) with a grim, categorically unjustified suspicion. "Oh, //I// see, Mr. Love Poems," she says, "you think you're //dangerous//."

[[div class="spacer"]]
[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK --]
[[/div]]

The book does not reply.

[[div class="spacer"]]
[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK --]
[[/div]]

Joint-stiff and a little embarrassed, Cecilia fetches an ice pack, evaluates, decides she's a little too heavy-headed to try the stairs again, and ultimately collapses into her armchair, wondering what sort of creature would eat at a sawdust restaurant, and what they would order. (Sawdust, probably…) She wakes up an hour past daybreak, having dreamnt of running through half-deserted streets as they eroded their skin into the wind, an endless dust making burrs of the air, grinding her coarse and then smooth and then smaller and smaller and smaller and smaller and — And all the way through, that feeling of someone unwelcome beside her, matching her stride for stride, breathing words into her ear to the pace of the run: //**Let** us **go** then, **you** and **I** — **you** and **I** — **you** and **I** — **let** us **go** then, **you** and **I** — **you** and **I** — **you** and **I**…//

[[div class="spacer"]]
[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK --]
[[/div]]

She loses the memory to blurry half-wakefulness, details first, the dream itself growing coarse and then smooth and then small as it recedes. Then she stands, feels herself stand, feels herself breathing in the uncontaminated air, unable to remember what made her think to classify it as uncontaminated. Something smells good: something good-smelling is near. The floorboards are creaking: someone approaches. She blinks her eyes back to functionality (this involves a closed-eyelids eyebrow-stretch that makes her ears thunder) and resolves the image before her into her smiling husband.

[[div class="spacer"]]
[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK --]
[[/div]]

No ambush today, no inquiry, no words even. Just a fresh ice pack and a steaming mug, held from underneath so the handle can face her. Trusting that she will, in time, explain the bruises and the chip in the flowerpot upstairs that she didn't even realize was the thing that her wrist had been having big opinions about.

[[div class="spacer"]]
[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK --]
[[/div]]

Her eyes blur back up, a bit, as she bites at her lip and gingerly assumes operational control of the coffee-vessel, about as much as she can manage right now. But that's already getting better. Words cannot express the love, the //gratitude// she —

[[div class="spacer"]]
[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK --]
[[/div]]

Well, alright, maybe //some// words.

[[div class="spacer"]]
[!-- THIS SPACE INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK --]

//**What a dork.**//

"...I am terribly sorry for the error, John. Sam was clearly too hasty with the deliveries…"

The man offers a forgiving nod. Until this moment, he had held out hope that the envelope was merely mislabeled, and contained an invite meant for him after all. "J.A.P., J.A.R., a pairing worthy of a comedy of errors, to be sure; please, don't trouble your boy over it. It was good fortune's happenstance that I noticed before opening the envelope."

"Yes, and thank you for its return, you have gone quite out of your way to spare me no small amount of potential trouble.[[footnote]]The "quite out of your way" and "no small amount" are pure affectation; now that Charles has secured a residence on Beacon Hill, the men live close enough to one another to regularly drop by unannounced and for no reason at all, and surely any potential trouble would have been meager. Still, these exaggerations bear no whiff of perfunctory condescension, and are warm with rapport.[[/footnote]] I will see to its inerrant delivery personally. And for all future correspondences, let me assure you that I will forevermore take the time to write out "John Arthur Prufrock" in its august totality.[[footnote]]From another's mouth, one might reasonably suspect a sarcastic intent here, but Charles is as earnest as ever.[[/footnote]] There would be no sense in tempting the Fates to meddle again."

"Indeed. Although, it would be John Alfred." Charles mumbles an apologetic acknowledgement, and there is a pause while John considers how to proceed; he settles on asking a question with an indubitable answer. "Speaking of correspondence. You would not happen to have the letter intended for myself?"

"I do not. I presume that Jeremiah[[footnote]]From — : "Jeremiah A. Robinson (1882?-1912?) was an American painter, etcher, and author of occultist literature, affiliated with the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_School_(painting) Boston School]; in the year of his disappearance, he was best known for public-facing roles in the Boston branch of the [https:// Hermetic Society of the Light Within All] and the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Guild_of_Boston_Artists Guild of Boston Artists], and for allegedly masterminding a series of bank robberies in the Boston area. These robberies informed several security procedures implemented at the Boston Federal Reserve bank at the time of its creation."[!-- although content generated for — is copyrighted by it, this passage was generated by user [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User:TheCureAtor&oldid=1275302681 TheCureAtor] in the course of her duties at the Boston Federal Reserve; consequently, the text is public domain.--][[/footnote]] has received it, and I will inquire as to its whereabouts when I deliver this. But I can inform you now of your letter's content, and offer you my condolences…"

This last word, of course, apprises John Alfred Prufrock of everything that needs to be told, and it strikes his solar plexus taut. Although the rejection is exactly what he conditioned himself to expect, and had been conditioning himself to expect from the moment he offered his work for apprisal, that conditioning was based in fatalist conjecture, and there was always the slimmest inextirpable hope of deliverance. Until now. "I see. Was any reason given?"

"Yes and no. The inquiry committee was quite effusive in their praise for your work, John. Two of the assessors in particular commended your poetry as a 'promising start,' a summation to which we all lent our support with great enthusiasm. It was decided unanimously to encourage you to continue in your efforts and to nurture your talent to its fullest achievable maturation."

"Charles. I am forty-two. I am not one of Mr. Benson's cherub-faced students.[!-- probably Frank W. Benson --] My submissions to your fanciful Society reflect decades of maturation —"

"... John …"

"— why, in this year alone I have been published in //The —//[!-- based on publication records, this was the title at the time of  , a monthly periodical that also published an annual almanac --] and reviewed in //New Literary World//[!-- not extensively documented, believed to be a now-defunct Boston publication from 1904 to the mid-1910s; this is only known from litigation of copyright infringement accusations from   , a rival publication that had bought out //Literary World// in 1904 --] — favorably —"

"— John! Please —"

"— if the fruits of such endeavors as mine amount only to a 'promising start' then perhaps I should prove a worthy mermaid[[footnote]]"Teach me to hear mermaids singing, / Or to keep off envy's stinging" –from [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Go_and_Catch_a_Falling_Star Song: Go and Catch a Falling Star], John Donne, c.1590s, pub.1633. Charles is unfamiliar with the poem, and hasn't the faintest idea what John meant by this.[[/footnote]] to your audience in a mere — few — centuries!" The last words are spittle-flecked; it is dawning on Prufrock that his anger must constitute quite a ridiculous spectacle for Atropos[!-- the Fate of death and other endings --] to enjoy. The burgeoning awareness of his asinine momentum is excruciating, a far-too-brightly-colored efflorescence that roots his guts and breaches his flesh.

"John!"

"You would do as well to praise Sisyphus for his 'promising start' toward cresting his hilltop!" With this, Prufrock looses the reins of Lyssa's chariot; having exhausted the remainder of his agitation, having expended himself to present audiences divine and Earthly with ample cause to guffaw or snicker at his expense, he withers, utterly, draining until there is nothing left to drain. He is a dry and sunless garden when the flowers are dead. His soil is bitter and laced with salt.

In theatre this would have elicited one last jeering round of snickers from the spectators, as it dawns on the Character that they have become the Fool. Here, there are not even witnesses, no utilitarian profit from his loss of dignity. He is the nova stella with no Tycho.[!-- Tycho Brahe, De nova et nullius aevi memoria prius visa stella, pub. 1573, public domain. --] He is the butt of a joke told to an empty room.

Charles is John's dearest friend. Charles knows that Charles is John's dearest friend (though it is hardly mutual). He chooses his next words, and his tone, accordingly. "John. We only admit a precious few, and the qualities that my 'fanciful' colleagues fancy are peculiar, even to me. And while I value the proficiencies we cultivate, we surely do not constitute a Trust when it comes to Enlightenment. This is an age rich in luminosity and luminaries, and there are also, surely, so many other Societies, of ours or greater esteem…"

"Surely." Prufrock is a speck alone, there are miles between him and any and all things; he is nothing left, an unmarked point in geometric space; he is a shell with the egg blown out. Empty, small, befouling the floor below.

Some simulacrum occupying Prufrock's space conducts the remainder of the conversation, politely. It walks the body back to its estate, an awkward locomotive many-jointed thing, and enters the rooms it uses to prepare itself for night-time. It has no need for a candle, nor for either of the electric light-switches; it knows the ways. It places his Decision into safekeeping.

Eons within, his ego is already healing. He is the unseen secret space inside a deep and winding cavern, a repository of unbreathed air. He is the point of intersection of infinitely many as-yet-undrawn lines.

He is an Adam with no spark,[!-- either a reference to Michelangelo's chapel painting     (1573, technically public domain but with active copyright assertions by Vatican authorities applicable to restorations and depictions of the original) or a reference to Mary Shelley's  (1818, public domain, but with a 1994 film of the same name asserting valid copyright) --] newly new, already reaching.

He //is// a seed, discarded, with the roots already breaching.

He //was// the soil in which this seed will grow.

Prufrock dreams of Michelangelo.

Lots of readers say the same thing about Whitman,[!-- poet Walt Whitman --] what with all the "I" statements. But in between those, Walt does take us on all those grand sweeping list-making journeys, with his "we are all one" bent to it. Prufrock gets outside his own head in the opposite way, by expressing alienation from everything and atomizing it, dwelling on the distance between.

To be real for a moment, it's not like readers actually need to know what the author had in mind, let alone understand perfectly; the consequences for error just aren't that big. It's a book, not an instruction manual for putting some bookshelves together. Nobody on the planet could ever possibly actually //need// to get it //exactly// right.[[footnote]]For the briefest moment, Cecilia feels very, very alone, and very, very far away.[[/footnote]] But the poem doesn't need to be exactly unambiguous to be impressive. Any communication has some wiggle room, error tolerance. Fiction has more leeway than most. Left turn or right turn, it wows me that an author can devise a way to accomplish this sort of communication //at all//, to any degree of specificity, without any words. Not to belabor the point, but poetry is its own very special sort of communication in this sense, and this was one of the first works I read that really cued me in to that, how structural elements of a work of literature are something more than just words and sentences and paragraph breaks, and maybe some funny extra line breaks and spacing and rhyming for the poems. I'm exaggerating the epiphany, but it really got my thoughts moving in ways that haven't stopped since. Not to mention it utterly, utterly ripped "show, don't tell" out of my mind and chucked it straight into the circular file.

What I'm describing is one of the most ass-backwards ways to write imaginable. There are so many horribly, horribly cheesy pitfalls to consider, something hacky like making a code out of the first letters of sentences, or counting words to put meaningful numbers between punctuation marks, or a million other possibilities just as gross and just as random, fundamentally arbitrary rather than integral. Ultimately that just means that, at best, the reader would be reading the text for the words and then going back and puzzle-solving the text as a whole separate exercise to squeeze out the rest of it. And that would totally compromise the value of structural data, which is for ##500|the recipient## to receive ##purple|the communication## as //effortlessly// as possible, carried right alongside the meaning accomplished by words. The effortlessness of the parallelism is the victory condition. The reader experience of //that// is that lovely spine chill when you //realize you know something//, even if the exact details of what the something //is// elude you, or, more exciting yet, you sense they are yet to be revealed, but you see them in outline. We don't need to have comprehension hit us all at once, but to circle allllll the way back around, this connects to your yearning for anticipation — for structural communication to succeed, we need to know immediately in our hearts and our spines that there is something there to be comprehended, and, if it's not yet obvious what that is, we need to feel some conviction that we're going to get there, ##purple|the key## is in our hands and awaiting ##500|the lock##, so to speak. The payoff is coming. With apologies to maybe a third of the authors I dearly love, if the reader needs to sit down with pencil and paper and a decoder ring to experience the spine-shivers of realization, are you writing a story or boxing out a crossword puzzle?

* A perception or cognition phenomenon, believed to be antimemetic, in which humans do not find the above changes as abnormal or bothersome. Prelimiinary testing suggests:
 * Subjects __do__ perceive the results of the change, e.g. smeared images, but do not consider these images remarkable or unusual, even if they have mnestic-recoverable memories related to what the unsmeared image plausibly would have been and what it would have represented.
 * When a discrepancy was pointed out to them, e.g. by prompting related memories, subjects invariably reacted as if the perceived text or image was not altered (and "had always been that way"), even when the "smear" was blatantly nonsensical in its context.
 * It was possible to persuade roughly 80% of preliminary test subjects affected by the phenomenon that a "smear" had not in fact always been that way, e.g. by pointing out it was nonsensical, in which case the subject invariably expressed disinterest ("not a big deal"), even in circumstances where the alteration blatantly compromised meaning or purpose.
  * Once persuaded of the existence of one example of the phenomenon, subjects were also able to perceive, identify, and describe other instances and recognize their present-day pervasiveness, but expressed disinterest in those instances as well.
  * Additionally, these subjects struggled to remember many of the instances they (presumably) previously witnessed, though they could and did form memories of instances they perceived from that point forward.
 * It was possible to persuade roughly 75% of subjects who expressed disinterest that the anomaly was in fact significant or worthy of consideration (e.g. by pointing out compromised meaning or purpose).
  * Once persuaded of the significance of one example of the phenomenon, subjects recognized the significance of other instances perceived from that point forward, often experiencing disorientation and commesurate anxiety consistent with the recognition.
  * Such a subject nonetheless only felt this concern about instances perceived after they had been persuaded, and did not express concern about instances they may or may not have encountered in the past. Although this was consistent with human researchers' own experience, and initially deemed non-anomalous, consulltation with multiple .aic have established that this is likely a persistent anomalous effect.
 * It appears that .aic are not currently subject to the above cognitive effects (this phenomenon was brought to the attention of human researchers through .aic-human interaction; .aic immunity has since been tested extensively). However, there is evidence to suggest that the "smear" phenomenon had initially manifested years prior to its discovery, implying that .aic may have been affected.
 * It is unknown whether this cognitive phenomenon affects any nonhuman sentient entities; researching this is low-priority.
* A poorly-understood meta/pataphysical thaumatologically-perceptible phenomenon currently designated "entry-entity pairing" in which existing text becomes affiliated, and/or additional text is generated and affiliated, with anomalous phenomena. Here "affiliated" is intended in the technical sense, cf. [https:// Supplemental Resource TCE-2092583], revision 15 or later; the full effects of this particular affiliation are not well-understood.
 * It was initially thought (and reported in an earlier iteration of this notice) that the above "pairing" phenomenon was limited to (a) Foundation documentation and (b) affiliation with currently contained anomalies, but both of these are now known to be incorrect.

++++ The anomalous phenomena have __not__ been observed manifesting in the following formats thus far.

* Audio records, the audio component of audiovisual files
* Spoken words, conversation
* Speech transmitted digitally, so long as the rendering on the recipient's end is acoustic
* Human memory
* Nonverbal body language with no text-representation component
 * a subject of current research, as proposed theories would imply that body language should be affected
 * some forms of body movement, such as tapping Morse code onto another person's palm, //are// subject to the effect
* Words formed from D-class lying down in positions that constructed letters, words, and sentences
 * means to exploit this peculiar exception are being researched
 * photographs, paintings, and video of these constructions //are// subject to the effect

+++ The following understanding of the summarizes our __current understanding__ of the phenomena as well as __directives and suggestions__ for the reader. It will be updated as frequently as feasible until the phenomena have been contained.

* Staff are **authorized to continue normal practices** for generating, uploading, and accessing text documentation.
 * Where possible, staff should attempt to avoid the use of **proper nouns** or comparable visual identifiers (logos, etc.) in written documentation, as the "smear" phenomenon appears to only affect them.
 * Use of **audio recording** for mission-critical documentation, e.g. Special Containment Procedures, is preferred at this time whenever possible. (Foundation interfaces are being adapted to allow for more efficient audio-based processes.)
* Although these phenomena were identified around the same time, and affect the same or similar aspects of reality, they **may be independent/unrelated** phenomena.
 * A lack of evidence of thaumatological manipulation in "smear" instances contrasts with invariably present evidence of thaumatological manipulation in "pairing" instances.
 * Further circumstantial evidence: the "pairing" and "smear" phenomena can affect the same text, with effects manifesting at different times. The phenomena's effects also sometimes partially overlap.
* With regard to the "pairing" phenomenon:
 * Entry-entity pairing is thaumatologically inert and must be invoked by the viewer of the documentation. The known methods for successful invocation are classified, but extremely unlikely to occur without reader intent. Acts such as downloading, viewing, reading, and/or generating documentation do not invoke pairings. In this sense, the only potential danger this issue presents to the reader is exposure to inaccurate information. **If you don't know how to do it, you're safe.**
 * Entry-entity pairing can be generated, manipulated, and removed through [[[a-brief-introduction-to-thaumaturgical-engineering|thaumateurgical engineering.]]] The preceding sentence of text contains an affiliation. Invocation can result in a variety of perceptual effects, including acquisition of information outside your clearance level. For this reason, invocation is prohibited. **If you do know how to do it, __don't__.**
 * Research thus far has produced useable invocations for: perceiving thaumatological affiliation corresponding to a pairing, invoking a pairing, creating a new pairing, and manually removing a pairing.
 * Manually removed pairings //sometimes// re-manifest, a process we are calling reversion. This sometimes happens effectively instantaneously, and sometimes happens with a delay, unpredictably.
 * Recent research suggests that manually removing pairings may in fact trigger additional instances of the phenomenon to occur. Containment protocol has been updated to prohibit manual removal.
 * To date, entry-entity pairing has not resulted in any **cognitohazardous** manifestation, or are (anti)memetic phenomena. (This is in stark distinction to the antimemetic "smear" phenomenon.) The "pairing" phenomenon is strictly metaphysical or pataphysical.
 * There is limited evidence to suggest that entry-entity pairing could technically present **a mild infohazard** to those who perceive it, in that merely perceiving the (existence of a) pairing may influence how the reader interprets the information they read, the same way presenting text ##green|in a conspicuously altered form## may [[[scp-4000|influence interpretation]]] of it. Simply ignoring one's own awareness of the phenomenon, and choosing to ignore and disregard its manifestations when they present themselves, is sufficient to fully protect the user from this infohazard.


+++ The following understanding of the summarizes our __lack of current understanding__ of the phenomena, to facilitate inquiry.

* Aspects of the manifestation are inconsistent: one printed text "copy" of a document may differ from another, text loaded from digital sources may or may not manifest different issues each time it is loaded, and a printed or digital document may have additional pairings manifest even while the user is reading. These discrepancies, and their causes, are not well-understood.
* Whether text stored in a digital format is affected, i.e. whether physical files have been corrupted or whether the effect applies whenever the file is read or interpreted as text or visual data, is unknown; comparisons of SHA-256 metadata suggest that the phenomena can sometimes manifest in different forms without changes to the underlying file, and sometimes its manifestation results in (physical) changes to the stored data.
* It is possible that one or more entities (with hostile, orthogonal, or even benign intent) are responsible for all of the manifestations of pairings, and could be stopped from making new ones. It is also possible that the manifestations are not conscious acts.
* It is of course always possible that personnel memories has been corrupted or changed, but no evidence of that has been discovered.
* The issues have manifested in documentation created both before and after the identification of the phenomena.
* The initial/original manifestations are not known, and may be unknowable due to as-yet-undocumented antimemetic effects. Mnestic-based research tentatively supports a tentative initial manifestation of the "smear" phenomenon some time in **2011**; efforts to narrow this range will continue, and a review of possible inciting events or relevant occurrences from that timespan is underway. Research into "pairing" is too
* The sources or causes of the data corruption/manipulations are unverified and under active investigation.
* The full extent of the data corruption/manipulations is unknown and under active investigation.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. You may now resume your regularly scheduled duties.
